title: Why don't more people use the Google Play Music? - Quora

response.answer_text: I recently used it for six months thanks to a free credit that came with my Chromebook. I didn’t pay when it elapsed, nor did I ever really consider it. Truth is, Spotify is better at nearly everything that matters: Spotify gets that people want to listen to an even mix of old favorites and new potentials, which they accommodate via their Daily Mix feature. Google makes you pick either/or (you can listen to a saved playlist or an impersonally-curated station).Spotify also offers Discover Weekly, which is a well-tuned way of finding new music that you’ll probably like. Google, meanwhile, doesn’t even offer a predictive service. Despite their enormous machine learning advantages, it seems like they don’t value the product enough to use said technology to improve it.Spotify understands social. Sharing songs is fun and intuitive. They also understand the role of musical tastes in self-identity, exemplified in their integration with Tinder and other millennial apps. Google, in contrast, is the company that invented G+.While both services offer Family Plans that multiple users can share to lessen the cost, Spotify has a far better network effect (more existing users means you’ll have an easier go of finding friends to split with).As a free/bundled service, Google Play is a decent music library. But the paid version is a hard sell considering far better competitors charge the same rate.

I started using Spotify first, just because it was what I’d heard of. But I switched to Google Play Music a couple years ago when Taylor Swift pulled her library off of Spotify. It works fine for me, but that’s because I usually know what I want to listen to. So 90% of the time, I listen to my own playlists. And I don’t usually get bored with that; I’ve been known to put the same song on repeat in the background while I’m working for several days at a time. I agree with the other answers that when I try asking Google to choose songs for me, I’m usually disappointed. They may be the world leaders in some areas of machine learning, but it seems like they haven’t cracked the code for music recommendations yet. I thought about switching back when Taylor Swift opened her library again, but I haven’t had a compelling reason yet. For some people I guess the social aspect of Spotify is important, but it doesn’t matter to me very much. Or maybe I’m just too lazy to set up my playlists all over again.
